Despite the shift in geography, the singer is picking up a thread he left hanging with 2010Ã¢â‚¬Â²s Band of Joy. On that album, Plant blurred boundaries between several musical styles, playing covers with a group assembled by producer Buddy Miller, but here he shifts that omnivorous aesthetic to a collection of originals performed with his ever-changing band the Sensational Space Shifters.

The Ceaseless Roar may not get loud Ã¢â‚¬â€ usually, when it rocks it sounds like a kissing cousin to a folk rave-up; sometimes, as on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Somebody There,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s chiming, crystalline, and bright like the Byrds Ã¢â‚¬â€ but it is intensely meditative, finding sustenance within mystery. Plant is reflecting on where heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been Ã¢â‚¬â€ singing Ã¢â‚¬Å“And if the sun refuses to shineÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ on Ã¢â‚¬Å“Pocketful of Golden,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ he tips a hat to his Zeppelin past; elsewhere he speaks of getting lost in America Ã¢â‚¬â€ yet gingerly avoiding questions of mortality and resisting the allure of easy sentimentality. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s possible to hear the weight of his years on lullaby andÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ The Ceaseless Roar Ã¢â‚¬â€ it is, in the best sense, mature music, dense in its rhythms and allusions, subtle in its melodies Ã¢â‚¬â€ but he never feels weary, nor does he traffic in false nostalgia.
